headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us and welcome to Fossil Group's Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Call. I'd like to remind you that information made available during this conference call contains forward-looking information and actu
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us and welcome to Fossil Group's Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Call. I'd like to remind you that information made available during this conference call contains forward-looking information and actual results could differ materially from those that will be projected during this call.
Fossil Group's policy on forward-looking statements and additional information concerning a number of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from such statements is readily available in our Form 10-K and 10-Q reports filed with the SEC. In addition, the company assumes no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise, except as required by law.
Please note that you may listen to a live webcast or replay of this call by visiting fossilgroup.com, under the Investors section.
Now I would like to turn the call over to the company's Chairman and CEO, Kosta Kartsotis.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining us today is Dennis Secor, our Chief Financial Officer. We will begin today's call with our prepared remarks and then open the call to answer questions. As we look back on 2014, we are pleased to conclude
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining us today is Dennis Secor, our Chief Financial Officer. We will begin today's call with our prepared remarks and then open the call to answer questions. 
As we look back on 2014, we are pleased to conclude another year of solid sales and earnings per share growth for the Fossil Group. The strength of our diverse business model, our team's disciplined execution of our strategies and our strong financial position drove overall results within our expectations.
We return value to our shareholders through the continued execution of our share repurchase program, while navigating unfavorable changes in currency at the end of the year. Importantly, we delivered strong results for the year while continuing to invest in the business to fuel future growth. And we drove efficiencies in our operations that position us to deliver solid returns for our shareholders well into the future. 
2014 included an 8% top line increase to $3.5 billion, an 8% reduction our share base as a result of continued execution of our share repurchase program. And we delivered $7.10 in earnings per share, an 8% increase over last year.
Changes in foreign currency aside, our fourth quarter included increased sales, robust growth internationally, very strong gains in jewelry, operating margin expansion, double-digit increase in earnings per share and was highlighted by continuing strength in our FOSSIL and SKAGEN lifestyle brands. That said, we are not entirely satisfied with our fourth quarter performance, particularly as it relates to our North America business.
We began 2015 intensely focused on taking advantage of the many opportunities available to us to drive future growth, including enhancing our multibrand portfolio to drive growth, investing in strategic initiatives to further grow our own brands and developing new categories that we believe can drive top line growth.
We reflect on this past year one in which we achieve our goal of maximizing the strength of our portfolio brands through our global distribution platform. We believe our portfolio of highly desirable brands, our continuous innovation, disciplined execution and considerable white space opportunity by brand category and geography has us well-positioned to continue our successful growth for many years in the future.
In 2014, we made solid progress on many key objectives that we will build upon in 2015. We grew our own lifestyle brands, FOSSIL and SKAGEN. Our FOSSIL brand grew at 3% for the year with growth in all regions. We leveraged our position as a leader in lifestyle branded watches and drove solid high single-digit growth in the watch category for the brand. The brand's growth was strongest in Asia with strong high teen growth in the region. 
Outside of watches, the year included to successfully position of our leathers business. We improved our performance in the category, particularly women's handbags, where we concentrated efforts to add to our design team and bolster our products to gain broader consumer appeal.
Our elevated assortment is resonating well with customers, particularly in our retail stores, where we have the best opportunity to clearly communicate the brand story and improve presentations through shop-in-shops within U.S. department stores.
We continue to believe FOSSIL jewelry is an opportunity for growth. And having spent this past year repositioning our U.S. distribution, we believe we are well-positioned to capitalize on synergies that jewelry shared with watches. In fact, the overall jewelry category is benefiting from the influence of lifestyle brands, and our compelling brands and developed distribution correct can facilitate growth in this category.
During the year, we turn our attention to direct investment toward demand creation opportunities that we believe will yield dividends for the brand in the future. We increased investments in our CRM capabilities, and we believe we are taking the right steps to achieve our goal of becoming world-class over time.
We also invested in brand building and demand creation activities, including marketing initiatives for FOSSIL. These are activities that we believe will broaden our customer base and drive increased interest and market share gains for the brand. 
This year, we made solid progress advancing SKAGEN. We achieved a 14% growth with sales accelerating in the back half of the year. The brand saw balanced growth across geographies with watches and jewelry posting solid, double-digit gains. We drove solid growth in jewelry, successful launch handbags and opened 2 new high-profile store locations in Frankfurt and New York that are performing well. These stores, along with our remodeled stores in London, allow us to showcase the full array of SKAGEN's product in an environment that reflects the differentiated and unique position of the brand.
Additionally, we enhanced our customer's digital experience with the brand with the launch of a redesigned SKAGEN website, which includes improved functionality for the customer and incorporates rich brand content designed to bring greater awareness to the brand.
In our portfolio, we continue to leverage our competitive strengths in branding, design, sourcing and distribution to gain increased market share and the growing watch industry. Our multi-brand watch portfolio grew 9% for the year with the strongest gains internationally. Across brands, we saw strength in long-standing brands, as well as newer brands, with Michael Kors, Armani, DIESEL and MARC by MARC all driving growth.
Our launch of the Tory Burch watch collection was highly successful and highlighted our design in Swiss production capabilities. We introduced the distinctive and Swiss watch assortment to a strategically targeted global distribution and expect to build upon the initial success of the line in the spring season. 
In addition to Tory Burch, we advanced our Swiss initiative with the spring launch of Emporio Armani Swiss-made. This Swiss opportunity represents one of the important white space opportunities we see available for lifestyle brand. And given our sourcing and production capability us, we are well-positioned to take advantage of the long-term opportunity with our license brands, as well as the continued execution of FOSSIL Swiss-made.
We also successfully executed 10-year renewals for 2 of our longstanding licenses, EMPORIO ARMANI and Michael Kors, solidifying our position at the national partner for the best global fashion brands. And today, we announced another exciting development with the addition of Kate Spade. This brand is clearly resonating with consumers globally and is positioned for long-term growth. We are excited to leverage our expertise in design, production and global distribution to grow their watch business and expand their brand around the world.
In another white space opportunity, we advanced our position in wearable technology with 2 very important partnerships with Google and Intel. We are partnering with the best in technology to deleverage their knowledge and expertise and enable our portfolio of lifestyle brands to develop fashionable, connected accessories. Our expertise in designing creativity, coupled with our partner's expertise in technology and innovation, will enable us to introduce wearable technology in a fashionable and scalable way. We are working towards integrating technology into our accessories in a manner that gives our focus on our core customer. We believe she prioritizes fashion with desires and improved functionality.
As we look forward to introducing connected accessories later this year, we are working towards a larger objective of leveraging our strength and leadership position and fashion watches to become the point where fashion, design and technology converge. We operate a very diverse business model with many levers of growth. We are globally diverse growth company and we operate in a growing industry. Our results this year continue to highlight this strength.
We achieved growth across each of our region this past year. This includes the Americas, a region that is nearly $2 billion today and includes our most mature market, United States, where we already have nearly 50% of the share of the watch market in the under $1,000 price point. 
In our international markets, as lifestyle brands take share from traditional watch brand, our goal is to replicate the success that we've experienced in the United States.
Europe continues to be strong for us this past year with 13% growth for the year and sales nearing $1.2 billion. This growth was balanced across markets. And we continue to have opportunity across Europe as we increase the number of our brands sold through existing doors, as well as expanding into new markets. 
In Asia, sales grew 15%, approaching $600 million with balanced growth across markets. Outside the United States and particularly in Asia, where we have a much smaller share of the existing watch market, the trend towards lifestyle brands is emerging. As it does, we believe the market dynamics are in our favor. And given the investments we have made in infrastructure in the region, we are poised to capitalize on that trend.
We believe the region, and particularly emerging markets in the region, represent a significant opportunity for us over the long term. As the world becomes increasingly globally branded, our watch portfolio continues to be a powerful tool to gain share in the growing global watch market. As an innovative category leader with world-class supply chain and a global distribution network of more than 30,000 doors, we are uniquely positioned to work with the best lifestyle brands around the world.
Our goal as a company to build a world-class entity of excellence, where creativity and entrepreneurs ship are carefully balance with operational discipline to enable us to deliver solid returns for our shareholders in the near and long-term. As a company, we're focused on using all of our resources to drive shareholder value. Growth and efficiency are key components of that, and you can see from our strategies and results that we are focused on those drivers.
We are also committed to leveraging our strong financial position. Last year, we invested $435 million to repurchase 4.1 million shares. We know that this is an important program for our shareholders, and we're fully committed to its. We are now operating with a share base that is more than 25% lower than it was just 3 years ago. 
Before I hand it over to Dennis, we would like to thank all of our associates for their inspired contributions this past year, as well as our partners and investors for their continuing support. As we reflect on the last year, we are pleased with the results but excited about our ability to improve of the company's performance. As we move ahead to 2015, our priorities will be very focused on the most important initiatives to driving growth.
We will invest to ignite our own brands, FOSSIL and SKAGEN, to increase brand awareness, increase demand and accelerate their growth. We will invest in our digital capabilities to improve the customer experience online and increase our omnichannel capabilities. And we will leverage our new partnerships to advance in the wearable technology space with a goal to launch connected accessories later this year.
We are well-positioned as a leader in a growing industry with a strong global footprint and significant competitive advantages. Our diversification gives us access to multiple sources of growth and supports our goal of predictable earnings and cash flows. Our operating model gives us opportunities for leverage and efficiencies to drive greater profitability. And our strong financial position gives us access to the fuel that we need to drive our business and to deliver solid returns for the shareholders.
Now I will ask Dennis talk us through the results and outlook for 2015.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kosta, and good afternoon, everyone. Fourth quarter net sales increased 3% in constant dollars, and on a reported basis, were flat to last year at $1,065,000,000. Sales for the quarter were below our expectation, as increases in our international
componenttext:
Thanks, Kosta, and good afternoon, everyone. Fourth quarter net sales increased 3% in constant dollars, and on a reported basis, were flat to last year at $1,065,000,000. Sales for the quarter were below our expectation, as increases in our international businesses and a strong performance in our direct business were offset by a decline in our North American wholesale business.
For the quarter, we delivered earnings per share of $3, a 12% increase over last year. Lower-than-expected sales were offset through expense reductions, which drove operating income growth, virtually all of which was consumed by currency headwinds. We benefited from a nonoperating gain, as well as a reduced share base.
The FOSSIL brand grew 3% in constant dollars and was driven by an increase in watches and leathers, partially offset by a decline in jewelry. We continue to be encouraged by the performance of the FOSSIL leather category, particularly the women's handbag business, which delivered strong comp results in our own stores during the quarter. SKAGEN sales grew 19% in constant dollars with strong double-digit growth in watches, an increase in jewelry, and our handbag assortment continues to do well following its third quarter launch.
Our multi-brand watch portfolio grew 2% in constant dollars with strong performances internationally. In North America wholesale, sales decreased 11% to $356 million and decreased 10% in constant dollar. Our U.S. sales performance accounted for the decline, nearly half of which came from lower off-price and liquidation shipment and the other half from lower shipments to major department stores. Shipments to boutique, a much smaller business, also declined. Our multi-brand watch portfolio saw the greatest volume decline for the quarter followed by leather, which continues to be negatively impacted by a highly promotional environment while jewelry grew over 20%.
While we're disappointed that we didn't maintain our third quarter selling momentum in watches, we believe that the change in sales trajectory was more a function of department store inventories than underlying sellout. The data we received from our U.S. department store partners suggest lower inventory levels have quarter end.
Looking back on the full year, as well as for the fourth quarter, we estimate that our watch business in department stores was modestly down with encouraging trends for many of our brands, including FOSSIL and SKAGEN. 
In leathers, while shipments declined in the quarter, the retail performance at women's leathers, the largest part of that business, was down only slightly, having improved steadily each quarter in 2014. We feel very strongly about our new products, and our goal is to see the same success in wholesale that we are already experiencing in our direct business.
Overall for the full year, our North America Wholesale business was essentially flat. In Europe wholesale, sales increased 3% to $281 million and increased 8% in constant dollars. Our European growth was driven by growth in our multi-brand watch portfolio and jewelry. We posted gains in most of our European markets with the strongest performance in the U.K., Germany and distributor markets, while Italy and Spain decline. For the year, European wholesale sales increased 12% in both consonant and reported dollar. Sales from our Asia wholesale operations increased 5% to $115 million and increased 10% in constant dollars. We posted gains in our own brands, as well as our multi-brand watch portfolio. We drove growth across most of our markets with particular strength in India, Japan and Australia. Our Duty Free business was strong, while our Korean business declined.
China continued to be challenging, both in terms of distribution expansion, as well as softening economic trends. And our business in Hong Kong is not as strong due at least in part to some of the political upheaval there resulting in fewer Chinese tourist. Concession sales increased during the quarter, while concession comps overall were down.
We ended the quarter with 334 concessions in the region. For the year, Asia wholesale sales increased 11% on a reported basis and 13% in constant dollars. In our direct business, fourth quarter sales increased 12% to $313 million and increased 16% in constant dollars. Sales growth was driven by store expansion and an 8% comp increase with all 3 regions delivering positive comps and with increases in jewelry, leathers and watches. We are very pleased with our retail business during the quarter particularly in the U.S. where we took advantage of improving holiday traffic.
With a great customer experience, compelling assortment and very targeted and tested promotions, we drove strong conversion and delivered a solid positive comp, the first positive comp in the United States since 2013. Our performance emboldens us to believe that we are on the right track with the FOSSIL brand. Our goal is to build on this momentum both in our stores and online.
During the quarter, we opened a net 12 stores, primarily outlets, bringing our company-owned store count to 593 at quarter-end. For the full year, direct sales increased 13% on a reported basis and 14% in constant dollars. Comps increased 2% for the year with increases in Europe and Asia Pacific, while North America was flat. For the year, we opened a net 50 new stores, primarily international outlets.
The fourth quarter gross profit decreased to $604 million and gross margin declined 60 basis points to 56.8%. The combination of international growth, a favorable channel mix and lower off-price volumes compared to last year all benefited gross margins in the quarter. These tailwinds were more than offset by changes in foreign currency, higher cost, as well as increased promotional levels, primarily allows us where we drove higher retail sales and profits with some compression in rates.
As we talked about on our last call, we feel we have reached an inflection point in our spending, pivoting away from infrastructure investments and focusing investment on initiatives to drive growth. In the quarter, operating expenses declined 2% to $382 million, with a reduction largely attributable through reversing incentive comp approval. Offsetting that decline was a very modest increase in infrastructure spending, small increase in direct retail expenses as well as increases in advertising royalties and demand creation activities. We leverage the expenses by 80 basis points. Operating income increased slightly to $222 million, including an $18 million unfavorable currency impact, and operating margin increased 30 basis points to 20.9%.
Interest expense increased $1 million to $5 million, given our higher debt levels. Other income for the quarter was $7 million, which primarily relates to a $6 million gain associated with the settlement related to our 2012 SKAGEN acquisition. Our effective income tax rate for the fourth quarter was 30.4%, compared to 30% last year. 
So overall, fourth quarter net income increased 4% to $154 million, as the declining gross profit was offset by lower operating expenses and a nonoperating gain. During the fourth quarter, we invested $117 million to repurchase 1.1 million shares of our common stock at an average price of $101, leaving $1.1 billion remaining our share repurchase authorization.
So now turning to our cash flows and balance sheet. For the full year, we generated operating cash flow of $377 million and drew down a net $122 million on our revolver. We used those funds to invest $435 million in share repurchases and $95 million in CapEx. We ended the year with roughly $276 million in cash compared to $320 million last year, and debt of $630 million compared to $508 million a year ago.
We ended the year with inventory of $597 million, a 5% increase over last year. In constant dollars, the growth rate was roughly 11%.
Now receivable decreased by 5% to $431 million. And wholesale DSOs were in line with the prior year. Depreciation and amortization expense totaled $22 million for the quarter and $96 million for the full year.
And now moving to our outlook. As Kosta described earlier, 2015 is clearly a pivot year for us with investments shifting from infrastructure to driving growth. We expect roughly 75% of our new OpEx investments will be focused on building brand awareness, engaging more with our customers, enhancing our digital presence, and developing and launching products in the wearable space.
We believe those investments position us well for growth, both in the near and long-term. We operate in a growing industry, and we believe our design, production and distribution capabilities makes us the best partner for global lifestyle brands. We're excited to add Kate Spade to our portfolio, an existing business that will have an immediate impact on our sales. Combination of their brand and our capabilities can be truly explosive on a global space.
We see opportunities in developing new categories, like wearable tech, and growing existing categories such as branded jewelry and leather. These opportunities do not come without challenges. While notable newcomers can help grow the market by bringing new customers into the category, they might also cause a near-term disruption. Managing the national ebbs and flows of brand lifecycles can also put challenging. However, our portfolio of diversified Brands can help navigate in these challenges.
While our European business has been very strong, China with its enormous potential, is taking long-range development. We expect that the factors that have driven our success in North America will play out in Europe and in Asia over time. We believe that the demographic and Asia are certainly in our favor, love the acceleration in growth may be further in the future, we are well-positioned with our infrastructure largely in place.
In North America, our most developed market, posted its own challenges as we work to protect our position and seek new opportunities for growth. Now specific to 2015, there are several factors that are significant and impactful to our financial results and will tend to obscure the underlying trends in our financial trends: Currencies, last year's extra week and the restructuring charge. To better understand our outlook, our 2015 analyses are done on a constant dollar basis and exclude the structure.
We'll also provide an estimate of the sales impact of last year's extra week. Estimating these factors and their impacts are not precise sciences and are provided to help gauge the overall impact of these factors rather than creating implied non-GAAP measure.
2015, we expect the overall 2014 sales trend to continue with a stronger sales growth coming from our international markets. We continue to expect strong performance from watches and jewelry with both Europe and Asia poised to gain share.
Overall, we're planning for continued growth in the multi-brand watch portfolio with opportunities from new and recently launched brands, as well as category expansion. We're very excited about our prospects in our international markets, particularly given the performance in Europe over the past year.
In the Americas, we're not planning on wholesale growth. We do see category opportunities in the region, particularly as we continue to inventory great success in branded jewelries. In our own retail environment, we've been very pleased with our most recent performance. And as we continue to invest in our own brands, our goal is to continue these trends and drive productivity improvement in our stores.
For the full year, we are planning constant dollar sales growth in the range between 3% and 7%. This excludes the impact of the extra week in 2014 estimated at roughly 1.25 points of growth.
For the first quarter, we are planning constant dollar sales growth in the range between 3.5% and 6%, excluding the impact of the extra week. This also include the impact of lower anticipated off-price sales compared to first quarter of 2014. 
Neutralizing for last year's extra week, the timing of price shipments and currencies, we see the first quarter trending at roughly the full year rate. With respect to 2015 growth margin, we expect strong international growth to benefit gross margins, which had helped offset the impact of higher cost.
We believe pricing can be an opportunity for further margin enhancement and continuously evaluate our pricing strategies to ensure our products are positioned appropriately and competitively. We executed on a very targeted price adjustment in the latter part of 2014 and expect that the competitive environment, particularly in light of currency changes, can create additional opportunities for pricing enhancement. Beyond that, our teams continue to work on initiatives to drive supply chain efficiencies.
Overall for 2015, our goal is to achieve constant dollar growth margin expansion. We expect modest constant dollar gross margin expansion in the first quarter and expect that our margin enhancement initiative to the extent we achieve them will yield improvements weighted towards the second half of the year. With respect to operating expenses, we plan to leverage our infrastructure and reinvest back capacities to drive growth.
We feel that the structure we need to support and grow our business for the foreseeable future is largely in place. Our second half 2014 infrastructure spending grew only slightly, and we expect that trend will continue. As a growth company, we will continue to look for opportunities to redeploy resources as our business evolves, and that can create some variations among quarters. 
Overall for 2015, we are planning nearly flat infrastructure spending with modest growth at the beginning of the year tailing off significantly as we anniversary last year's leveling of infrastructure and realize benefits from our efficiency initiative.
For 2015, we will continue to make significant marketing investments to support the expansion of our portfolio brands and would fund incremental investments to ignite FOSSIL and SKAGEN. Continuing to build out our digital capabilities is critical for our strategy, and we are earmarking funding to enhance those capabilities.
And with a solid partnerships already in place with tech giants like Google and Intel, we are poised invest in connected accessories and support a product launch later in the year. 
2015, in addition to our ongoing marketing investments, we plan to invest up to $35 million or $0.50 per share to support of these critical strategic initiatives. We expect the highest relative increase for our marketing investments will come in the first quarter, as we anniversary a very low level of spending last year and in the fourth quarter, as we invest to support our holiday business. We expect roughly 20% of our expense growth will come from investments in our direct businesses, mainly concessions, which require far less capital than store.
We expect store-related expense growth will be highest in the first quarter, tailing off as we anniversary stores added last year. Our strategy in 2015 is to expand our digital presence and open fewer stores, a net 10 new stores focused on international outlet.
Lastly, as I mentioned in my fourth quarter review, we reduced our incentive comp expense in 2014 as we did not achieve all of last year's goal. Our 2015 expectations include an assumption of success against our 2015 goals, which would then result in an expense headwind in Q4. Inclusive of all these investments, we expect our overall expenses to grow in the high single-digits. We expect the highest growth rates to be in the first quarter, which also include the impact of earlier expenses from Baselworld.
We expect the expense growth will be lowest in the middle 2 quarters, increasing again in the fourth, given our marketing investment and expectations around incentive comp. Taking all of these factors into account, we expect full year constant dollar operating margins to be roughly flat to down 80 basis points. As gross margin expansion and infrastructure leverage offset the impact of growth investment. For the first quarter, we expect constant dollar operating margins in the range between 9.5% and 10.5%.
As we mentioned on our last call, currencies will have a material impact on our financial results for 2015. In November, we estimated the impact in our 2014 results that the then prevailing rates would have been in effect for the full 2014 year. That estimate adjusted for the first 3 quarters of 2014, but anticipated no Q4 headwind should the guidance assumes prevailing rate as of November.
Since then, the U.S. dollar has further strengthened against most currencies that affect us, especially the euro, which is the currency that impacts us most. The euro average in the mid $1.30 in the first 3 quarters in 2014 and was roughly $1.25 when we spoke in November. Since then, the euro depreciation have accelerated, particularly since year-end, reaching roughly $1.14 today. 
Now the impact in the first 3 quarters of 2014 has more than doubled and there is a significant currency headwind in the fourth quarter as well, which is the quarter in which we earned roughly 40% of our operating income.
That much larger 2014 headwind will now expand further as we move into 2015, given most of our earnings growth will come from our international businesses and our gross margins will be further impacted by the rapid strengthening of the U.S. dollar. Based on prevailing exchange rate, we estimate that the net impact on our 2015 result, inclusive of hedging program offset, will be roughly $1.20 per share.
We'll continue to look at pricing as a potential offset, so any pricing opportunities we may pursue would have a delayed impact and will primarily be dependent on the market's competitive environment. At prevailing exchange rates, we estimate the negative impact on our 2015 revenue growth will be roughly 500 basis points as the negative impact in both gross and operating margins will be more than 250 basis points. We expect the quarterly top line headwind of roughly 600 basis points until we reached the fourth quarter, when the headwind will be roughly half that amount.
The absolute EPS headwind should build and intensify as we move through the first 3 quarters and then stabilize in the fourth where the relative currency headwinds will be much smaller so the earnings base should be larger. 
With respect to restructuring investment. While the process of optimizing our operating structure is always ongoing, we feel we are in the later stages of near-term infrastructure investments. In 2015, we plan to invest roughly $25 million or $0.35 per share to refine and optimize our structure, creating greater efficiencies and improving our retail profitability. These initiatives primarily emerged from the detailed strategic planning process that we undertook last year. These investments will include the remainder of the store closures that we announced in 2014 that were not completed by last year-end.
We believe these investments all have compelling near-term paybacks, including some benefits later this year, and just as important, will support our efforts to create a best-in-class operating platform capable of responding quickly to our many growth opportunities.
And we expect the vast majority of these charges will be recorded in the first half of this year with about $10 million or $0.14 per share impacting the first quarter. 
On a reported GAAP basis, including all the factors I mentioned, we anticipate full year revenues in the range between a 1% increase and a 3% decrease. For the first quarter, we expect to report revenues that are down between 5.5% and 7.5%. For the full year, we expect reported operating margins between 12% and 13%. For the first quarter, we expect operating margins in the range between 6% and 7%.
We expect full year GAAP EPS in the range between $5.45 and $6.05 per share, which includes the negative impact of the $1.20 currency headwind, the $0.35 negative impact from the restructuring charge and the $0.50 impact from our strategic investments. These amounts assume that currencies remain roughly at the prevailing rates and include net nonoperating gains associated with currencies both contract and account balances. They also assume a higher level of interest expense, given increased debt, continued investment in our share repurchase program and a tax rate of roughly 31%. 
For the first quarter, we expect GAAP EPS in the range between $0.59 and $0.69 per share, which includes a $0.14 restructuring charge and a $0.17 currency headwind. We are planning CapEx of roughly $120 million. We expect that our capital investments will generally shift away from new store openings to investments to build our digital and CRM capabilities, as well as incremental shop-in-shop. Before I turn the call back over to the operator for your questions, we would like to remind you about our Investor Day being held in Dallas the afternoon of March 5. We look forward to sharing our long-term outlook with you and hope that you plan to join us either in person or through the provided audio webcast. 
So now, I'll turn the call back to the operator for your questions.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Randy Konik with Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Randy Konik with Jefferies.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess, can we talk a little bit -- get a little bit more flavor around the disconnect between the wholesale side of the business in North America and the retail side? So it sounded like your comments suggested that there wasn't necessarily a sell-thr
componenttext: So I guess, can we talk a little bit -- get a little bit more flavor around the disconnect between the wholesale side of the business in North America and the retail side? So it sounded like your comments suggested that there wasn't necessarily a sell-through issue in the wholesale channel, but more of a sell-in item. Is that -- I mean, based on your conversations with your key partners, is it -- do you -- are you under the, I guess, understanding, are they trying to destock or maintain conservative inventory posture ahead of the Apple Watch launch in the spring? Or kind of what are your conversations with your partners kind of telling you about how they're trying to think about inventory levels and thinking about the upcoming launch of that particular watch?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, first of all, keep in mind, it's just 1 quarter and we did have increases for the full year. Also keep in mind, in the third quarter of last year, we actually had a 9% increase in watches in the United States. So some of this may have been bui
componenttext: Okay. Well, first of all, keep in mind, it's just 1 quarter and we did have increases for the full year. Also keep in mind, in the third quarter of last year, we actually had a 9% increase in watches in the United States. So some of this may have been building stock for Christmas. We also know, as we mentioned, is that the sellout comp percent in our wholesale partners in the United States was not -- it was slightly negative down, but not down as much as our wholesale shipments. So having said all of that, there's a lot of moving parts going on. The market is, I think, in United States, still -- we still think it's a very important category for the stores. Extremely profitable. There's a lot of activity going on. We're launching Tory Burch. We're expanding to more doors. Kate Spade is already in there, but we'll be expanding it. We are hopeful to put some wearable technology in the space. This, in 2015, could spark interest and bring more people to the counter. But as far as the watch trend is concerned overall, Euromonitor says that in the United States and globally, the Watch business still grew at 4% last. They're expecting it to grow 6% the next several years. We think we're in position to continue to gain share in a growing market, and we'll keep pursuing that with as much innovation and branding and ideas that we possibly can.

And just how you think, over time, you can leverage the brand portfolio that you have to really further grow that business. And then I have a follow-up for Dennis.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the China market, the retail environment, as you know, has been somewhat choppy the last couple of quarters or so. We are still continuing to pursue new initiatives, new locations. We do have some new management in the region, which we're very excit
componenttext: Well, the China market, the retail environment, as you know, has been somewhat choppy the last couple of quarters or so. We are still continuing to pursue new initiatives, new locations. We do have some new management in the region, which we're very excited about. We think it will follow. But having said that, it's a difficult complicated market. And we expect there will be a very significant opportunity for us long term. So we're continuing to pursue opportunities and build out the infrastructure, and we're sure that it will be someday, a very significant business. And then your time, it's not going to grow quarter-to-quarter and it mean your fashion. It's going to be somewhat choppy, we think, and we'll continue to pursue it.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Dennis, from an FX perspective, when you look at that $1.20, can you just help us think about 2 different aspects of that. One, how are you hedged currently? And when do those start to roll off and start to adopt from a structural perspect
componenttext: Okay. And then, Dennis, from an FX perspective, when you look at that $1.20, can you just help us think about 2 different aspects of that. One, how are you hedged currently? And when do those start to roll off and start to adopt from a structural perspective, the significant deceleration we've seen in the euro? And then secondly, can you just speak to any of the impact that you're seeing from your Swiss headquarters right now, just given the rapid appreciation of the Swiss franc?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: So yes, let me just step back and kind of give you a view of the overall currency environment here. We talked about the $1.20 headwind. Roughly half of that will come from translation. That means, as we're translating our foreign earnings in the U.S. doll
componenttext: So yes, let me just step back and kind of give you a view of the overall currency environment here. We talked about the $1.20 headwind. Roughly half of that will come from translation. That means, as we're translating our foreign earnings in the U.S. dollar, each line item on the P&L obviously translates into a lower amount. So in the consolidate of that into U.S. dollars, that all combines to represents half the half of that headwind. So that's the part that we don't hedge. Now the other half, the $1.20, relates to the transaction through our foreign sub buy inventory primarily in U.S. dollars. So as the dollar strengthens, their cost of goods goes up, and obviously, their margins are reduced. Now we do hedge that exposure with foreign contracts based on our order estimates. obviously, with the greatest visibility and the very near term, our program runs roughly over 18 months and we dollar cost average into the rate. So the hedging offset is highest in the near quarter up to roughly 2/3 and then tails off over time, averaging just under about half of a full year offset as we head into 2015. So that's helped offset the impact. Although, remember, the offset is recorded below the line in other income. So that net impact is the other half of the $1.20 headwind. Now in addition to forwards, we've already implement price increases, some last year, with more to come very soon, and we're still working on more later in the year. So obviously, their success depends on market condition. So we can get predict the full impact. However, if you combine our contract hedges, along with the price adjustments we are planning combined, they would virtually offset the full P&L impact. Now at the margin rate, but the contraction will P&L impact of the strong U.S. dollar at those rates. So that's the overall currency environment. Then with respect to the Swiss franc, we fairly automatically or naturally hedged with that. And as much is our Swiss franc expense base roughly in the line with our revenue base.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015

componenttext: Regarding the lower shipments, what's incorporated in your outlook in terms of how the retailers may act in terms of their inventory management? Will that trend continue in your -- and what do you include in your guidance? Also, could you just speak a little bit to wearables? Are all your brands going to embrace this? And do you think the route to market will be similar? And I know you have changed pricing in the past and sometimes you've gone too far in pricing. So what gives you confidence that you can have some investments and which parts of your portfolio may have better elasticity to pricing of interest there?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So with respect to the general assumptions of that into guidance, we look at the trends coming out, region-by-region, coming out of '14 with the assumptions that those trends roughly continue. We still assume, as Kosta mentioned, the Euromonitor data
componenttext: Yes. So with respect to the general assumptions of that into guidance, we look at the trends coming out, region-by-region, coming out of '14 with the assumptions that those trends roughly continue. We still assume, as Kosta mentioned, the Euromonitor data, where we understand with respect to watch category growth, we see continued international growth opportunities for share gains there. FOSSIL has been on a great trend recently, positive comps positive coming into the year, improving wholesale trends with wholesale partners. SKAGEN grew double digits, accelerated towards the back half of the year. Branded jewelry leathers have been trending well for us, new brands. So there's a lot tailwinds in there. There's also some risk we talked about. New entrants into the market in North America continues to be a little bit choppy for us. And we are constantly managing these ebb and flow in portfolio. So we've tried to do our best to gauge the sum total of those risks and opportunities in the range that we provide you. As we've said, before, we don't -- we're not providing guidance to try to do anything other than give you a range of what we think some reasonable possibilities and outcomes are.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: As far as wearables go, we're doing basically is building up from for ongoing growth in the category. So we're looking at both display items like smart watches, but also nondisplay items, like jewelry and potentially bracelets, et cetera. And we think eve
componenttext: As far as wearables go, we're doing basically is building up from for ongoing growth in the category. So we're looking at both display items like smart watches, but also nondisplay items, like jewelry and potentially bracelets, et cetera. And we think eventually, it'll probably impact all brands. One way to look at this is if we have a business in wearable technology that involves fashion with some technology, whether it's sensors or communication, theoretically, potentially someday, every watch we make could have some type of technology. So expect, some point, all our markets will have advanced technology, whether its sensors, committee Catia that could be apps in the community involved as well. And that's really the approach we're taking. So as I said, who will be shipping us something later this year. The cores group has actually been meeting this area and has been brought a lot of discussions to us about wearable technology are working closely with them. And we're in discussion about all other brands about the appropriate time to bring out some products.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015

componenttext: Can you talk about the promotional environment for watches in general? I know that demand has been a bit choppy in the U.S. So are you seeing elevated promotions continue early in new year? And what's your outlook for the rest of this year? And then secondly, a question on inventories. There seem to be up a bit more than your anticipated sales growth. Can you provide some context there? Is it having certain categories or brands? And should we expect sales to off-price retailers to be elevated in the near term as you adjust that?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, on the promotional activity. Watches is one of the least promotional categories of fashion products in the United States, and we like at that rate. And we have been doing everything we can to inspire an ongoing trend in that. We actually thi
componenttext: First of all, on the promotional activity. Watches is one of the least promotional categories of fashion products in the United States, and we like at that rate. And we have been doing everything we can to inspire an ongoing trend in that. We actually think in the fourth quarter last year, there was actually less promotional activity than there was the prior year. So we're pleased with that trend. And we look forward to continue to keep this at the regular price. And also, keep in mind, it's mostly regular priced business. Margins are very high investors. Averaging retails are very high. And we want to continue to feel it with new brands and ideas and innovation and technology. That's really our idea, and we think we can do that. On the inventory site, when we look at both the inventory and our wholesale partners stores and also, our own inventory, we think we're in good shape. We ended up in our own inventory slightly up, but that was mostly of the sales miss. But the practical matter the Chinese year is coming in and our global funded organization will observe that and we'll get going. Also keep in mind that we have a good part of our inventory, especially in watches and lump Quick Response items. So it's really just a process of managing the ebb and flow of quick response items so we should be able to work to pretty quickly.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two quick ones. Dennis, the guidance for Q1 in the fiscal year, you gave us sales. I know you committed you don't expect North America wholesale to grow. Can you tell us what's embedded for North America wholesale for Q1 and for the fiscal year? And then
componenttext: Two quick ones. Dennis, the guidance for Q1 in the fiscal year, you gave us sales. I know you committed you don't expect North America wholesale to grow. Can you tell us what's embedded for North America wholesale for Q1 and for the fiscal year? And then also around the restructuring. Should we be modeling store closures as we model out the next 12 months to the BTC segment?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So generally, we didn't specifically guide to regional sales growth. I think the best way to look about it is generally, we assume the trends continue coming out of '14 of the full year trends. And we also typically, and you'd see that in those numbe
componenttext: Yes. So generally, we didn't specifically guide to regional sales growth. I think the best way to look about it is generally, we assume the trends continue coming out of '14 of the full year trends. And we also typically, and you'd see that in those numbers, would expect the regions to act and grow relative to their own level of maturity. So the international businesses drive the most growth for us. Europe is a very strong. Asia has been growing in double digits. And North America is a region where we're not anticipating wholesale growth, are very encouraged by the retail comps. So we -- our goal is to see those trends continue. With respect to store closures, I mean, what we said is that we're opening a net 10 stores. Most of those stores will be overseas. In fact, we should operate with fewer stores by the end of the year here in North America. So most of the or all of the growth will be international and we will execute some closures here. That's also what some of the cost in those restructuring charges will facilitate.

componenttext: You mentioned several times kind of 2015 being a transition year. Kind of shifting from distribution, I'm sorry, infrastructure building mode to more of a growth mode. Asia, China, to kind of exploring the FOSSIL brand and SKAGEN brand opportunities to extend those brands. The smart watches, you've got a few different partnerships. You've got some new brands that you're signing license with. But help us understand in the context of this -- the U.S. kind of core multibrand watch quarter this quarter, I know it's just one quarter. But just help us understand just kind of your core, most profitable business, the multi-brand watch platform. Are we getting ahead of ourselves and focusing alluded to much of the growth? Or how do you ensure that core business remains stable, remains profitable and remains steady, what's your strategies around that, I guess both in U.S. and Europe, I think both are pretty big businesses.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again, we had a 9% increase in the third quarter. And all along, we've said that the U.S. business has grown dramatically, as you know, over the last 5 years. The stores are doing, in a lot of cases, multiples what they were 5 years ago. So all a mu
componenttext: Well, again, we had a 9% increase in the third quarter. And all along, we've said that the U.S. business has grown dramatically, as you know, over the last 5 years. The stores are doing, in a lot of cases, multiples what they were 5 years ago. So all a much higher avenue in retail businesses really been incredible, high-margin, high impact. There's a lot of awareness in watches. People love them. The efforts we've had in other companies with branding and innovation has really been well-received. It really high relative to apparel, which has had deflation. So it continues to be a great category. But the business is very significant and it's been one quarter we're we had a tough quarter wholesale. We didn't see that the department stores having they were slightly down and not come especially with the store product. We don't know what they wear totally, but not a precipitous fall. We still think that with all the things we have in place, FOSSIL and SKAGEN still will continue to grow. As we mentioned, Tory Burch's just in a small number of doors and the United States will grow. We think we can expand Kate Spade and the rest of our portfolio. We do have a -- there's a lot of opportunity with us putting the more ideas and more brands and continue to make the category for us especially if you consider that wearable technology can have play in that. So there's a whole bunch of activity going on that we think will continue. But having said that, and our biggest opportunity our on-site in the United States.

componenttextpreview: So just follow up to Omar's question. Kosta, you've been making a lot of investments in the company over the last couple of years, I say, probably 2 in terms of inferred. How does the advent of wearables change the way you think about those investments? A
componenttext: So just follow up to Omar's question. Kosta, you've been making a lot of investments in the company over the last couple of years, I say, probably 2 in terms of inferred. How does the advent of wearables change the way you think about those investments? And given that you're thinking wearables could potentially impact all of your watch brands, should we expect the investments now to shift into a different category wearables, et cetera, than probably from where you are investing before distribution, infrastructure, things like that?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we think we -- by investing in wearable technology, enables us to leverage the global platform we have. We sell 30,000 points of sale globally. We have a number of brands and access to more. We have a big share, at least, mindshare in the marketplac
componenttext: Well, we think we -- by investing in wearable technology, enables us to leverage the global platform we have. We sell 30,000 points of sale globally. We have a number of brands and access to more. We have a big share, at least, mindshare in the marketplace. And we think we have the capability of bringing convergence of passion and technology together, so we can make great-looking products that have an emotional attachment to customer that love brands, but also have a little extra functionality. And if you look at, from our perspective, the huge amount of spending going on in technology products. So phone, cellphones, iPads, so services, however, if you look at the huge amount of serving in the category and Watch businesses relatively small. It's just a small percentage of the standing, drop down watch business could have a dramatic impact on the growth of the category, make it more relevant. And we think we're sitting right in the middle of something that can be much larger. So there's a lot of moving parts. We are very excited to be investing with our partners, both Intel and Google and others, son coming up with new ideas to engage customers, have the communication vehicles and really enable customers to make their watch and their wearable technology more relevant to their lives. I think it puts, it makes the watch category much more relevant especially when you consider the millennials watchdog were up without watches. They have cellphone when they grew up and they don't necessarily more to watch. But now with the branding and technology come into play, we think we've got a big opportunity.

componenttextpreview: Just wanted to circle back on the new brands that you have. Tory Burch, I know you said is in just a small number of doors. So I just wondered how we should think about that brand will expand this year. And then, Kate Spade, you've talked about an immedia
componenttext: Just wanted to circle back on the new brands that you have. Tory Burch, I know you said is in just a small number of doors. So I just wondered how we should think about that brand will expand this year. And then, Kate Spade, you've talked about an immediate impact on sales. If you could just provide a little bit more color on where they are, what kinds of things you think you can add to the brand at this point.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, in Tory Burch, as you know, we launched last year. And it's typical when we launch a new brand, we start out slow, small number of doors, expand slowly based on demand and sell through, wait until we get the operating model correct and then we expan
componenttext: Well, in Tory Burch, as you know, we launched last year. And it's typical when we launch a new brand, we start out slow, small number of doors, expand slowly based on demand and sell through, wait until we get the operating model correct and then we expand it. So most of our license things we started have been relatively small for the first couple of years until we were ready to expand it. And I think Tory Burch will be the same situation. We see a great response. We're learning a lot. I mean, the brand is unique, and we think it's going to be terrific. So we're very excited about that. Kate Spade, it is an existing business. They've been watches themselves. That I did a great job. They have a good business with strong point of view. And we're very excited to work closely with them. Since it's an existing business, it already has space, et cetera. So we'll be able to add on that and add additional doors globally and with the expanded. So it's -- you could say it's a little bit further along in the process than Tory Burch's because it's been around for a couple of years. And that's -- we think a good thing for us, and we look forward to working closely with them.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015

componenttextpreview: I guess, to follow up on the previous question, the thinking with Kate Spade addition. How do you guys balance just the development of in-house and licensed portfolios so not to cannibalize some of existing brands? That's our first question. And just to f
componenttext: I guess, to follow up on the previous question, the thinking with Kate Spade addition. How do you guys balance just the development of in-house and licensed portfolios so not to cannibalize some of existing brands? That's our first question. And just to follow up. What drove the acceleration in direct-to-consumer in the fourth quarter? Did you say watches comped positively in North America? And how did outlet performed versus mall based stores?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: The first question in terms of Kate Spade and how -- the way we look at it. First of all, our biggest objective is to grow our own brands. So FOSSIL and SKAGEN, and they continue to grow nicely last year. One thing I would mention specifically about FOSSI
componenttext: The first question in terms of Kate Spade and how -- the way we look at it. First of all, our biggest objective is to grow our own brands. So FOSSIL and SKAGEN, and they continue to grow nicely last year. One thing I would mention specifically about FOSSIL is that we did start accelerating our expense -- our expenditures on marketing, especially on digital and social last year. And we did see a result, both in our own stores, and that's why the DTC number that you mentioned went up. We actually, in the month of fourth quarter, we actually had the best quarter we've had in some time. And we -- our metric show that a lot of that was due to relatively small amount of money we spent on additional advertising last you. And as we mentioned, we're going to accelerate that this year. We also will have that we're investing a lot in omnichannel and CRM capabilities that will enable us to accelerate those marketing investments. So we think we're in a really good place on the FOSSIL brand. Having said that, we do, in our portfolio, our mission is to have the biggest and the best brands in the world, the ones where investment and store growth is growing so we can continue to grow our share of the watch business. So Kate Spade fits really well in that. And we think it's going to have a significant long-term potential. But that's really our mission is to make sure that we have in our portfolio the best brands in the world had the ones where the most vestment will go behind it.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just on the comps, the fourth quarter comps. We were positive in watches, leathers, jewelry, all of those comped positively, and we were up in both outlets and in full-price accessory.
componenttext: And then just on the comps, the fourth quarter comps. We were positive in watches, leathers, jewelry, all of those comped positively, and we were up in both outlets and in full-price accessory.

componenttext: Well, then let me take the second part first. And as we look out over the next foreseeable horizons, we don't see significant changes in our overall business model. I think that's -- we can talk -- we will talk, don't know if you will, be year a few weeks, but we will give you more visibility on our we're thinking about the near-term and what some of the puts and takes will be. But that's something that we can share more in a couple of weeks.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: One comment I would add about the economics in wearable technology. One of the exciting things about wearable technology is that over the next couple of years, as technology gets better, battery life is going to be better, the size of the objects will be
componenttext: One comment I would add about the economics in wearable technology. One of the exciting things about wearable technology is that over the next couple of years, as technology gets better, battery life is going to be better, the size of the objects will be better, the functionality will be better and the economics will be better because as the quantities grow, then the cost, et cetera come down pretty quickly. So that's probably why we think its very compelling long-term opportunity.
