headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you guys could talk a little bit more about the wholesale dynamic in North America. You talk about your retail partners managing inventory very tightly right now. I guess, how much are they shrinking the open-to-buy dollars on the overall wat
componenttext: I was hoping you guys could talk a little bit more about the wholesale dynamic in North America. You talk about your retail partners managing inventory very tightly right now. I guess, how much are they shrinking the open-to-buy dollars on the overall watch category? That would be my first question. I've got a couple of follow-ups.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: We haven't seen a significant pullback on the inventory flow, and it looks to us when we analyze it, it looks like it's relative to the sales, which obviously the trend is down, but inventories look to be in good shape for us for the back half of the year
componenttext: We haven't seen a significant pullback on the inventory flow, and it looks to us when we analyze it, it looks like it's relative to the sales, which obviously the trend is down, but inventories look to be in good shape for us for the back half of the year and we'll move forward from there, but we don't see any significant pullback.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I guess if I look at your sales guidance for the fourth quarter then, is that all just sell-through rates decelerating to that range? Or is there an assumption that there is effectively no reorders from -- or something else more draconian than th
componenttext: Okay. So I guess if I look at your sales guidance for the fourth quarter then, is that all just sell-through rates decelerating to that range? Or is there an assumption that there is effectively no reorders from -- or something else more draconian than that in the fourth quarter guide? I'm just trying to understand that dynamic.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, this -- it's -- we experienced in the third quarter, sequentially, we saw a slowdown in each one of our businesses. So we believe that given where we are, that we could see some tightness everywhere. Europe is actually the largest change in the w
componenttext: Yes. No, this -- it's -- we experienced in the third quarter, sequentially, we saw a slowdown in each one of our businesses. So we believe that given where we are, that we could see some tightness everywhere. Europe is actually the largest change in the way we've been thinking about the fourth quarter from where we were before. So we've lowered our expectations to accommodate the fact that we think that the fourth quarter could not be as strong as we had anticipated going in. I mean, we always operate with a relative limited visibility, so a lot remains to be seen. And most of the business is done in the second half of the quarter. We don't operate with backlog, but we've left a fairly wide range to accommodate lower sell-in and sell-through.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess just last question on Michael Kors, you did highlight that a number of times in your prepared remarks, just on the kind of comping, the pretty tough comps from last year. When do you think we officially cycle that? Or how much more
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess just last question on Michael Kors, you did highlight that a number of times in your prepared remarks, just on the kind of comping, the pretty tough comps from last year. When do you think we officially cycle that? Or how much more kind of pruning or kind of rightsizing at the brand needs to happen? Because it does seem, to your point earlier, that Europe is now starting to go through that reset on that -- on the brand. So just curious on how you think about that over the next 12 to 18 to 24 months.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: As we said, we're going through some pretty tough comparisons, mostly in the U.S. and Europe. But in the meantime, we're ramping up a lot on men's on automatics. We're adding additional assortments and locations for jewelry. We're building more shop-in sh
componenttext: As we said, we're going through some pretty tough comparisons, mostly in the U.S. and Europe. But in the meantime, we're ramping up a lot on men's on automatics. We're adding additional assortments and locations for jewelry. We're building more shop-in shops. Asia is still in its infancy for Kors, so there's a lot of opportunity there. And the big opportunity over the next couple of years is going to be adding wearables to this. We think it could turbocharge that business quite a bit. So -- and in addition to that, I would say that the Michael Kors business is still extremely productive, our most productive brand, very powerful globally. So we expect that the business will probably settle a bit, for a while. We'll get wearables in there next year, and then we'll set it up for more long-term growth. It's a very strong global brand. It's unique in the world and it's a great brand and one where we're very pleased to go to battle with over the long term.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Omar Saad with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Omar Saad with Evercore ISI.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: So wanted to follow-up, my first question on the wearables piece, a lot of stuff going on there. It's obviously a really tiny percentage of your business now. But you mentioned there's some data that you're seeing that gives you a lot of confidence in thi
componenttext: So wanted to follow-up, my first question on the wearables piece, a lot of stuff going on there. It's obviously a really tiny percentage of your business now. But you mentioned there's some data that you're seeing that gives you a lot of confidence in this, obviously enough confidence to make a sizable acquisition. Help us understand: a, where are you getting this confidence to make this kind of bet on the wearables piece? And then maybe a little bit more details around Misfit specifically, the app platform versus the hardware side, what the key ingredients are there that you can leverage in your existing businesses?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Greg McKelvey. Yes, in terms of the confidence in the size of the category, it's -- I think first is we're seeing the market develop, where it's increasingly clear to us that wearable technology is and will be a large growing category. There's pro
componenttext: This is Greg McKelvey. Yes, in terms of the confidence in the size of the category, it's -- I think first is we're seeing the market develop, where it's increasingly clear to us that wearable technology is and will be a large growing category. There's projections out there that are putting it at about $45 billion in the next 4 or 5 years with roughly 2/3 of that being wrist worn. That would put the size of that market at roughly the same size of the under $1,000 global watch market. And we believe that all 3 categories that make up that market, which would be activity trackers, smart watches with display and then the third being smarter watches, so integrating technology similar to what you'd find in activity tracker into the same type of watches we sell today, all 3 of those are viable products that are -- that we see actually our FOSSIL Q launch being very successful with. So we're going -- part of that, we see the market's developing and we have a position to play in it. With Misfit, it's -- we've learned a lot in the last couple of years in developing product and bringing it to market, FOSSIL Q. We believe that we're now in a connected age where apps and cloud services are effectively now part of product and an extension of brand and that needs to support and mirror our business model of today, so meaning multi-brand, fashion- and design-driven and globally scalable. And it's so integral now to product and brand development that it's really too important to outsource that to somebody else. So we need -- we want to own that customer experience, own the platform, be able to have -- be -- get to market much more quickly. And then as we scale it across the breadth of our portfolio of brands in 20 languages in 115 countries, just the pure economics of scaling our product size, breadth, number of brands across the fixed cost of the development of that platform makes for much more attractive margins ultimately than we'd get if we fully outsourced it.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then -- sorry, just to add one other thing. Misfit, specifically, they've got a very talented team that spent the last 4 years solving some of the hardest problems in wearables, including battery life, and their platform has already, because they've g
componenttext: And then -- sorry, just to add one other thing. Misfit, specifically, they've got a very talented team that spent the last 4 years solving some of the hardest problems in wearables, including battery life, and their platform has already, because they've got -- is already supporting multiple brands, given their partnerships with Swarovski and Victoria's Secret and others. They're global, especially with strengths in the U.S. and in Asia, which is important to us. They've got an 18-month pipeline of products and innovation that we're going to be able to extend not only into the Misfit brand but into the full breadth of our product portfolio and brand portfolio. And then it's a digitally native brand, as we discussed on the call as well, that allows us to get into consumer electronics and health care and enterprise and other channels we're not in today. So a significant opportunity to expand our addressable market.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's clear to us that wrist devices are selling. They're selling in terms of trackers and also in new entrants in smart watches. You could say for our overall Watch business that there -- we have a fashion miss, which is we don't have technology acro
componenttext: Yes, it's clear to us that wrist devices are selling. They're selling in terms of trackers and also in new entrants in smart watches. You could say for our overall Watch business that there -- we have a fashion miss, which is we don't have technology across our platform. There seems to be, in just the general watch business, that people are maybe waiting to see, they're looking for technology, they're not sure. In the meantime, wrist devices with technology are selling extremely quickly. So we think that one of the most important fashion trends right now in the industry is this huge interest on the consumer side of the convergence of fashion and technology. And we are moving very quickly to make sure that we can scale technology in many different ways across our platform, as we mentioned, not just in Android display smart watches but across our entire platform of devices and watches, putting sensors and connectivity, et cetera. And we think, actually, at some point, everything we make will have some type of chip in it that will add additional functionality and not at a lot of additional cost because of the fact that we make 50 million pieces of accessories a year and it's going to enable us to scale it across our entire organization. But it's all the stuff we've talked about in the past. And one thing is millennials clearly overspend on technology. There's a -- seems to be a slowdown in consumer activity overall, but one thing that's clear is consumers are still spending on technology and we think that continues. We also know that from our past, consumers will spend on additional functionality. A lot of our growth over the last 5 years has come from us adding chronographs and other technical features that are higher average retail and consumers are very willing to spend it and that's one of the things we're going to be putting in there. The other thing to remember is the watch industry is fundamentally a small business, about $65 billion globally. So the projections on the wearable business are that it's going to grow very quickly and at some point will be of the same size as the watch business. But if you look at the trillions that's being spent on technology right now from all different types of cellphones and service and games, et cetera, if a small percentage of that spending comes into our accessory business, it can make a huge impact on it and that's what we're working for. And this acquisition also gives us the ability to innovate and differentiate us from our competitors. We're going to be able to put products on the market that are unique and special and address people's lives in many different ways and it's going to be a very unique and long-term opportunity for us to differentiate and to innovate like we do in the rest of our business.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could just one more thought to that, we absolutely remain at the core of the traditional watch market, but what this allows us to do is really to be all things to all people on the wrist. So whether it's design, fashion, style or brands or now tech a
componenttext: If I could just one more thought to that, we absolutely remain at the core of the traditional watch market, but what this allows us to do is really to be all things to all people on the wrist. So whether it's design, fashion, style or brands or now tech and the additional functionality in the app community that, that brings, we think that we have the products to merge that together and we can do it in a way that nobody else can.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could bring the wearables conversation to line it up with the Michael Kors conversation, do you think that female, I don't know, 20- to 40-year-old Michael Kors fashion watch consumer that have been buying watches has now switched and is buying Fitbi
componenttext: If I could bring the wearables conversation to line it up with the Michael Kors conversation, do you think that female, I don't know, 20- to 40-year-old Michael Kors fashion watch consumer that have been buying watches has now switched and is buying Fitbits and Apple watches? Or do you think she's on the sideline because she's waiting to see what's going to happen to the space? Or was there a lack of newness and innovation and new products for her within the Michael Kors line that a majority had enough products and styles? Help me understand what you think was going on between that wearables and Michael Kors specifically, because it is so big and was such a big growth driver.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Excellent question. What we've seen from Kors is a huge audience of Kors fans out there that over the last 10 years have fallen in love with the brand and have bought Kors products that the overall look of that is what we would call boyfriend. So it's a m
componenttext: Excellent question. What we've seen from Kors is a huge audience of Kors fans out there that over the last 10 years have fallen in love with the brand and have bought Kors products that the overall look of that is what we would call boyfriend. So it's a men's watch on a woman. Most of those customers, a lot of them have multiples of those watches. And I'd say one thing we haven't done, which we're working on right now, is we haven't innovated off of that idea fast enough, and you're going to see a whole new assortment of Kors watches next year, even before the wearable technology comes in. We're going to totally change the look. It's more modern, simpler, et cetera. There's a totally new look for it. It gives the consumer, the Kors fan, a reason to buy another watch. But clearly, when we put the wearable technology on there and we put -- Michael Kors himself gets behind it and the entire power of that organization is talking about technology and how can it fit with the Kors lifestyle, et cetera, we think it's another catalyst for another phase of growth. And I think that's -- the idea of technology injecting with fashion is so relevant today, especially with the millennial customer. We think it's going to fit and dovetail perfectly in with our long-term Michael Kors strategy.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: So to summarize, you think it's a combination of lack of the wearable technology but also maybe a little bit lack in newness and innovation.
componenttext: So to summarize, you think it's a combination of lack of the wearable technology but also maybe a little bit lack in newness and innovation.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely.
componenttext: Absolutely.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Rick Patel with Stephens.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Rick Patel with Stephens.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. First on the FOSSIL Q Founder, does have the 1-week battery life as well or is that just the FOSSIL Q Grant that you were referring to? And then secondly, any color on the pricing of FOSSIL Founder and perhaps the economics of
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. First on the FOSSIL Q Founder, does have the 1-week battery life as well or is that just the FOSSIL Q Grant that you were referring to? And then secondly, any color on the pricing of FOSSIL Founder and perhaps the economics of it? Since you're partnering with Google and Intel, I'm curious about how each unit sold is going to impact sales and profitability. Dennis, I think you mentioned the negative impact of lower margins, but any way to frame that quantitatively?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Greg. The Q Grant has a week or more battery life. Q Founder will have a day to 2 days depending on use. Price points on Q Founder are $275 to $295 and then Q Grant is $175 to $195. And then in terms of economics, we don't release margins on these
componenttext: This is Greg. The Q Grant has a week or more battery life. Q Founder will have a day to 2 days depending on use. Price points on Q Founder are $275 to $295 and then Q Grant is $175 to $195. And then in terms of economics, we don't release margins on these products. I'd say that compared to where the growth that we're expecting for Gen 2 and Gen 3 over the next 12 and 18 months, we're going to see a heck of a lot more unit volume and margin expansion as we go into next year. I'd still call generation 1 our first foray into the market. Limited inventory risk that we took in Q4 as we're just sort of starting to see how the products perform. But we're getting app store -- both on Apple and Google App Stores very good scores. It's performing really well at both wholesale and our own direct-to-consumer channel. So we're going to start to step into more volume as the holiday season goes on and early next year.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, just to add on the margins. Well, Greg is right, we're not giving specific details. The volumes in the fourth quarter are relatively low. The way we think about this going forward into the future is that we do expect, as it becomes a larger part of t
componenttext: Yes, just to add on the margins. Well, Greg is right, we're not giving specific details. The volumes in the fourth quarter are relatively low. The way we think about this going forward into the future is that we do expect, as it becomes a larger part of the mix, that there should -- that should drive some downward pressure just because the category historically has not been as strong a margins as we yield. On the other hand, as we scale, there should be some opportunity for the scale economics to kick in and help offset some of that. But over time, the way we think about it now is we'd expect some general margin headwind. Having said that, Kosta alluded to this, that as we add innovation to products, there's an opportunity for us to claim greater price and drive AUR. All of that remains to be seen. But if you're thinking about next year, this should probably give us a little bit of margin headwind.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: One thing that -- just in the tech industry, and especially with our -- the expertise we're going to gain from Misfit is, everything is going to get better. Battery lives will get better. Chips are going to get better and less expensive. The objects are g
componenttext: One thing that -- just in the tech industry, and especially with our -- the expertise we're going to gain from Misfit is, everything is going to get better. Battery lives will get better. Chips are going to get better and less expensive. The objects are going to get smaller and we'll be able to put next year or shortly thereafter women's smart watches out there. Our Android smart watches at some point probably net next year will be untethered, which means you don't need your smartphone with you, but all of this is going to get better, especially with us having the expertise to be an innovator and be on the front edge of all this technology and work with partners, et cetera, we're going to be able to bring more compelling products that will look better, feel better. Margins will be better. And we'll be able to add a lot of function to fashion without a lot of intrusiveness. So we're going to be in a pretty good position.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And as you roll out wearables, are you going to have to augment your display cases in department stores and jewelry stores versus what you have for analog watches? And if so, how should we think about the impact it's going to have either on depreciation o
componenttext: And as you roll out wearables, are you going to have to augment your display cases in department stores and jewelry stores versus what you have for analog watches? And if so, how should we think about the impact it's going to have either on depreciation or expenses or CapEx?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've already done that. If you can see the Q presentations, at both our stores and also in department stores, you'll see that we've added some in-case and top counter and some other display. But as a -- it's a matter, of course, we refresh those an
componenttext: Well, we've already done that. If you can see the Q presentations, at both our stores and also in department stores, you'll see that we've added some in-case and top counter and some other display. But as a -- it's a matter, of course, we refresh those anyway on an ongoing basis, so I wouldn't say it's any additional cost. Generally, it's more just changing from one thing to another. So it is going to be part of it but it shouldn't be a big expense.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other thing I'd add is this is also a big part of the value of the Misfit platform. So their technology is built on replaceable coin cell or watch-type batteries. So their whole software runs on those. What that allows us to do is very quickly scale b
componenttext: The other thing I'd add is this is also a big part of the value of the Misfit platform. So their technology is built on replaceable coin cell or watch-type batteries. So their whole software runs on those. What that allows us to do is very quickly scale both smarter watches and activity trackers that use those coin cell batteries across our global sales organization across all channels without having to worry about putting power and expensive fixtures in place. So it gives us speed and much lower cost in operating expense and in CapEx.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Simeon Siegel with Nomura Securities.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Simeon Siegel with Nomura Securities.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sorry if I missed this, but is the goal for Misfit to take the place of Intel and Google for all the connected devices? And I guess if that's correct, what happens to the devices you have in the interim? And then, Dennis, can you just talk about the confl
componenttext: Sorry if I missed this, but is the goal for Misfit to take the place of Intel and Google for all the connected devices? And I guess if that's correct, what happens to the devices you have in the interim? And then, Dennis, can you just talk about the conflicting factors mentioned in the press release of pricing initiatives versus the higher markdowns that we have on this quarter's gross margin?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Greg. I'll take the first one. The -- in terms of our technology partnerships, Intel and Google, who are both of our announced partnerships, they have been fantastic partners and will continue to be partners with us. The Misfit acquisition is real
componenttext: This is Greg. I'll take the first one. The -- in terms of our technology partnerships, Intel and Google, who are both of our announced partnerships, they have been fantastic partners and will continue to be partners with us. The Misfit acquisition is really about owning the cloud and the app platform, given how integral it is now to product and brand and customer experience. So we'll own that part of the customer experience through the app and cloud, but we will continue to partner with the leading technology companies across the world to continue to build the right ecosystem of partners that compete in this space. So we'll -- the best hardware providers, the best contract manufacturers, the right ecosystem, cloud partners, whether that's music or fitness or what have you. So it's -- it still takes an entire ecosystem. This is just us -- about us owning the cloud and app platform that's now part of product and brand.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of the margin. The pricing -- generally speaking, the pricing adjustments that we've made, we've seen the margin yields that we were anticipating for the year, sales have not materialized as we had expected. So inventory levels, as you saw,
componenttext: Yes, in terms of the margin. The pricing -- generally speaking, the pricing adjustments that we've made, we've seen the margin yields that we were anticipating for the year, sales have not materialized as we had expected. So inventory levels, as you saw, are certainly higher, and so we will be likely then moving more inventory through different channels. That would put some pressure on the margins that we've included in the guidance, but to manage our inventories at appropriate levels.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the higher markdowns are on different products than what you were able to take the price on?
componenttext: Okay. So the higher markdowns are on different products than what you were able to take the price on?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's different products. And I also mentioned that we're a little heavy in Swiss and we'll likely invest a little there to make sure those levels of inventory are appropriate.
componenttext: Yes, it's different products. And I also mentioned that we're a little heavy in Swiss and we'll likely invest a little there to make sure those levels of inventory are appropriate.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Lindsay Drucker Mann with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Lindsay Drucker Mann with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just -- I wanted to get some context around your outlook for smarter accessories and watches versus traditional ones. And given some of the headwinds you cited for millennial consumers and their acceptance of traditional watches and embracing digital on
componenttext: I just -- I wanted to get some context around your outlook for smarter accessories and watches versus traditional ones. And given some of the headwinds you cited for millennial consumers and their acceptance of traditional watches and embracing digital ones, how we should think about the risk to your traditional watch sales for next year?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- I think what we're -- the -- our view is that we're at a point now where this is a natural evolution and we see these markets coming together, where those who traditionally have not participated in the traditional watch market, they're no
componenttext: Well, I think -- I think what we're -- the -- our view is that we're at a point now where this is a natural evolution and we see these markets coming together, where those who traditionally have not participated in the traditional watch market, they're now more accessible to us because we have the ability to add tech to the product. So we are -- and I said a few minutes ago, I really -- the way we view this is that we now got the best of both worlds in that we can be all things to all people on the wrist. So that if to the extent that you're a customer for whom design, fashion, style, branding matter and you're not interested in tech, we still are advantaged there. This expands our arrow, another arrow in our quiver to attack additional market and go after additional consumers.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd add one other -- sorry, I'd add one other data point for you. That remember, 65% or 70% of our revenues today are female fashion-conscious customers and the smart watch market in particular to today is still male-dominated. Females are playing in the
componenttext: I'd add one other -- sorry, I'd add one other data point for you. That remember, 65% or 70% of our revenues today are female fashion-conscious customers and the smart watch market in particular to today is still male-dominated. Females are playing in the activity tracker space. So it's really not replacing for female fashion-conscious customers anyway, smart watches are not having a large overlap today. So we see, however, an opportunity for all 3 of the categories that we're going to be bringing to market to support and drive growth with that customer, that core customer.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. But as we think about your -- the speed at which you could scale these new platforms and have to build them and some of the lead times, should we be thinking about your North American business as one that can -- given some of the headwinds you tal
componenttext: Got it. But as we think about your -- the speed at which you could scale these new platforms and have to build them and some of the lead times, should we be thinking about your North American business as one that can -- given some of the headwinds you talked about in the traditional category, should we be thinking of that as a business that can grow next year? Or are your anticipating further revenue pressure?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we haven't yet guided for 2016. So -- but the way I would think about it is the acquisition itself provides us for opportunities for tailwinds for growth for next year, Misfit by itself, our ability to accelerate that growth through our own distributio
componenttext: So we haven't yet guided for 2016. So -- but the way I would think about it is the acquisition itself provides us for opportunities for tailwinds for growth for next year, Misfit by itself, our ability to accelerate that growth through our own distribution sales force and our ability to leverage our platform -- or the Misfit platform across some of our brands. That will be later in the second half of the year and it won't include all of the brands on the platform next year, but there will be tailwinds there. FOSSIL and SKAGEN, we see as tailwinds in 2016. Every region, those brands are growing in. We're seeing benefits from the marketing investments that we are making. And our omni investments are also yielding dividends. Our e-commerce business has been up. So there's a lot of tailwinds going into next year. What remains to be seen is what are the -- and we really need the fourth quarter to get better informed about this. What are the category trends? How is the consumer feeling? Economic trends, brand trends. So we need more and we'll learn more through the fourth quarter. But we see a portfolio going into next year that includes a number of tailwinds including -- this acquisition will provide many of those.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Oliver Chen with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Oliver Chen with Cowen and Company.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kosta, what do you think are the near-term differences that you can make to simulate demand? I know the sell-ins are mostly done for the holiday season. But as we look to spring, are you going to have a radically changed assortment across all your brands,
componenttext: Kosta, what do you think are the near-term differences that you can make to simulate demand? I know the sell-ins are mostly done for the holiday season. But as we look to spring, are you going to have a radically changed assortment across all your brands, including Kors? Or is Kors kind of the main focus for transformation? And then the watch market, did it also decline double digits? I'm just curious about how the market moved versus your constant currency results.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Actually, we're moving very quickly across our entire spectrum of products with innovation and new materials, new ideas, changing as much as possible, changing point of sale. You could even -- if you see our FOSSIL store, for example, and you saw we'
componenttext: Yes. Actually, we're moving very quickly across our entire spectrum of products with innovation and new materials, new ideas, changing as much as possible, changing point of sale. You could even -- if you see our FOSSIL store, for example, and you saw we've had pretty good results in there, we've totally changed the way we have our presentations done. The products look great and we're showing some pretty good increases relative to the market. So this is a typical pro forma for us. When times get tough, we innovate like crazy and put more designs in there, take some chances, et cetera. And typically during tough times, we come out of it in pretty strong growth. Our operating model is really built for resilience and flexibility. Our inventory turns are faster than the rest of the market. Our design innovation is better and quicker. Our resources are broader and have a larger scale. Just giving you one example is that we -- globally, we use -- most of our business is done through our own wholly owned subsidiaries where our competitors largely use distributors. When times get tough, distributors pull back in inventory investments, et cetera and we just keep going. So this is the time for us to get stronger, take more share while we're moving very quickly, to disrupt the market with new innovation, with technology and new ideas, et cetera. So we think we're in a pretty good position. Over the next couple of years, we think it will play out pretty well for us.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then on the U.S. market, the data that we collect, independent data covers not all but a substantial part of the market, about 40% of the U.S. market at our price points. And as I mentioned on the call, when we exclude the impact of Kors, we see us --
componenttext: And then on the U.S. market, the data that we collect, independent data covers not all but a substantial part of the market, about 40% of the U.S. market at our price points. And as I mentioned on the call, when we exclude the impact of Kors, we see us -- our Watch business outperforming the U.S. market in the third quarter at our price points.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Ed Yruma with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Ed Yruma with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess first, I know historically you haven't provided markdown support for your wholesale partners. But I guess what do your -- or can you do in a time like this where sales trends are deteriorating pretty meaningfully? And then second, I know you've ta
componenttext: I guess first, I know historically you haven't provided markdown support for your wholesale partners. But I guess what do your -- or can you do in a time like this where sales trends are deteriorating pretty meaningfully? And then second, I know you've talked about wearables having a lower margin profile. I guess, maybe a little bit more color, and I know obviously this is changing with your acquisition.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, the one advantage also in our operating model is that watches, accessories, they're not typically -- there's not a weather-related component to it. There's not a lot of seasonality. It's not like swimwear and shorts and outerwear, et cetera. So
componenttext: Yes, well, the one advantage also in our operating model is that watches, accessories, they're not typically -- there's not a weather-related component to it. There's not a lot of seasonality. It's not like swimwear and shorts and outerwear, et cetera. So the margins that retailers get are relatively high. And it's not typically been a big part of our ongoing business model. We don't expect that to change dramatically. As far as the wearables, as we've been talking about, we have a lower gross margin now. But we think over long term, as quantities come into play and we scale this across our platform, that we can actually have a situation where we're able to increase that over time. Just looking at Moore's Law, chips get less expensive and more robust, and we think that will play out for us, especially with our quantities and how we're going to go to market and especially also with us having the expertise to develop this ourselves rather than rely on third parties largely to do most of it.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the other aspect of longer term, as you think about the margins, even to the extent that their gross margins are modestly expanding or even if they're still creating a headwind, we think that there's an opportunity to leverage the entire infrastructu
componenttext: Yes, the other aspect of longer term, as you think about the margins, even to the extent that their gross margins are modestly expanding or even if they're still creating a headwind, we think that there's an opportunity to leverage the entire infrastructure and the platform across all of our brands and distribution and that provides us a lot of power to drive operating margin expansion over time. We won't see that immediately because we're not getting all the benefits of leveraging the platform over the portfolio all the way in 2016, but over time, we think that could be significant.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And one follow-up, if I may. You mentioned that FX, obviously and some of the hedges you have, won't be working in your favor next year. Is that simply just looking at that other income line and assuming that, that goes closer to 0?
componenttext: Got it. And one follow-up, if I may. You mentioned that FX, obviously and some of the hedges you have, won't be working in your favor next year. Is that simply just looking at that other income line and assuming that, that goes closer to 0?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's right. It's exactly right. You won't have the benefit of those contracts because most of those have run out.
componenttext: That's right. It's exactly right. You won't have the benefit of those contracts because most of those have run out.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll move to our next question from Ike Boruchow with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll move to our next question from Ike Boruchow with Wells Fargo.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one on your Q4 sales guidance. I mean, when you look back historically, you've guided within a range of 2 points. This year, it's 9 points. I'm just -- if you can give us some more detail about the visibility that you have. I mean, historical
componenttext: Just a quick one on your Q4 sales guidance. I mean, when you look back historically, you've guided within a range of 2 points. This year, it's 9 points. I'm just -- if you can give us some more detail about the visibility that you have. I mean, historically, you've had some predictability there. And just kind of the ongoing discussions with your wholesale partners maybe region by region, just trying to understand the sell-in, sell-out kind of dynamic that you're dealing with day to day right now?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said before, what we don't have is a lot of visibility. We don't operate with backlogs. What we do, do is we analyze our business in a lot of different ways. We look at it regionally, by category, by brand. I did say earlier, the biggest change
componenttext: Well, as I said before, what we don't have is a lot of visibility. We don't operate with backlogs. What we do, do is we analyze our business in a lot of different ways. We look at it regionally, by category, by brand. I did say earlier, the biggest change in the way we're thinking about the fourth quarter comes from Europe, where going into this last quarter, we had seen 1 quarter of less favorable performance following about 7 or 8 quarters of very strong double digits-or-so growth coming out of Europe. So the trajectory changed there fairly quickly so we've adjusted our expectations. I mean, we're coming off of a down 7.5 third quarter, up against a 10. We've we provided a wide range to reflect a relatively choppy environment right now that's difficult to predict and we want to be able to accommodate in our range the deteriorating trends. The second quarter, we saw a step down from Q2 going into Q3. And most of the business in the fourth quarter happens in the back part of the quarter. It's going to be largely dependent on reorders and how our wholesale partners are looking to manage their inventories at their year end.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And Dennis, can you just -- when you said the acquisition was -- I think you said it was dilutive to '16, was that dilutive to your margins or dilutive to your EPS? Just want to make sure.
componenttext: Got it. And Dennis, can you just -- when you said the acquisition was -- I think you said it was dilutive to '16, was that dilutive to your margins or dilutive to your EPS? Just want to make sure.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Both.
componenttext: Both.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Anna Andreeva with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Anna Andreeva with Oppenheimer.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to Dennis, an earlier comment about needing to invest in the business. Can you maybe talk about the puts and takes on the gross margin versus SG&A lines as we think about 2016? Could next year, I guess, be a down earnings year for FOSSIL given some o
componenttext: Just to Dennis, an earlier comment about needing to invest in the business. Can you maybe talk about the puts and takes on the gross margin versus SG&A lines as we think about 2016? Could next year, I guess, be a down earnings year for FOSSIL given some of the investments? And also a question on the store footprint. You guys have been adding new doors at a pretty healthy clip. Should we expect that to change as the focus shifts towards wearables? And any opportunity -- additional opportunity to close doors?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: So, again, in terms of growth, thinking about next year, so a fairly near-term kind of lens on this I would expect, just because of the nature of wearables, we would expect to see some modest headwinds in the gross margins in terms of the way we're planni
componenttext: So, again, in terms of growth, thinking about next year, so a fairly near-term kind of lens on this I would expect, just because of the nature of wearables, we would expect to see some modest headwinds in the gross margins in terms of the way we're planning the expense line. We have been holding infrastructure tight and we think that is the way we're going to manage 2016. We've actually been operating with very limited store growth, and we would expect to continue to do that into next year. One thing that we have to work through that we don't have yet, is just what are the purchase accounting implications of the Misfit acquisition and how that will likely affect the expense line. But what we believe is that -- I mean, this is the hottest category right now and now is the time for us to invest. We're seeing traction from the investments that we're making in FOSSIL, in SKAGEN, in Omni and we intend to continue to do that and really drive the top line. Again, we talked about it on the last call -- or the last question rather, currencies are going to impact our earnings because in 2015, you really saw it in the operating margins but the earnings were lifted up because we had the nonoperating contracts supporting it below the line. Now in 2016, we're going to be anywhere from 1.5 years to 2.5 years outside of when the dollar really started strengthening. So the contracts only buy you time and now that's been neutralized. So even in the base business, all other things being equal, the currencies, because of the lack of those nonoperating gains, are going to create earnings headwinds.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll move to our next question from Heather Balsky with Bank of America.
componenttext: And we'll move to our next question from Heather Balsky with Bank of America.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just talk about how you're thinking about your SG&A investments next year outside of marketing around the wearables, if -- especially if you do see greater-than-expected sales weakness in the fourth quarter, would your plan be
componenttext: I was wondering if you could just talk about how you're thinking about your SG&A investments next year outside of marketing around the wearables, if -- especially if you do see greater-than-expected sales weakness in the fourth quarter, would your plan be to invest more in marketing to drive awareness to drive traffic?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is where -- I mean, as I just said on the last -- the framework for us for next year is hold infrastructure, stores tight but invest where we're seeing returns. And we're seeing returns in FOSSIL and SKAGEN. In the third quarter, those brands were bo
componenttext: That is where -- I mean, as I just said on the last -- the framework for us for next year is hold infrastructure, stores tight but invest where we're seeing returns. And we're seeing returns in FOSSIL and SKAGEN. In the third quarter, those brands were both up, and there's not a lot of brands that are able to drive growth in a pretty challenging environment. So where we're seeing returns, we expect to invest. Omni-channel is another investment where we're seeing good solid returns in our E-com business, and those are the areas we're going to invest. Again, wearables is hot right now. This is the time for us to be investing in it and that's the way we're approaching 2016.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of more points on top of the marketing investment. We are investing, based on last year's results, in very targeted ways, largely digital and almost all traffic-driving. So very good returns, more short-term focused and we -- it gives us th
componenttext: I had a couple of more points on top of the marketing investment. We are investing, based on last year's results, in very targeted ways, largely digital and almost all traffic-driving. So very good returns, more short-term focused and we -- it gives us the ability also to quickly respond to the effectiveness that we're seeing. So -- and then on omni-channel investments, we have some pretty good leading indicators so far on the investments paying out, not just in the traffic and conversion improvements that we're seeing online, but L2 recently came out with some reports that put us as a top mover in the space compared to the rest of the fashion peer set and initiatives that we're deploying now are just going to continue to drive momentum there. And then on the social side, we're seeing a lot of momentum as well with pretty significant follower growth and sentiment. So those all give us a lot of confidence that the investments are paying out and will continue to compound as we go into next year.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a separate question in terms of your direct performance. I was wondering if you could just quickly tell us how outlet performed compared to your full price channel?
componenttext: Okay. And then a separate question in terms of your direct performance. I was wondering if you could just quickly tell us how outlet performed compared to your full price channel?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me -- I'm remote today. I don't have those data in front of me and maybe somebody can grab and I can get that in just a second.
componenttext: Let me -- I'm remote today. I don't have those data in front of me and maybe somebody can grab and I can get that in just a second.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Laurent Vasilescu with Macquarie.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Laurent Vasilescu with Macquarie.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you provide a bit more color on the composition of the inventory by product category? Should we see watches are up high single to low double digits year-over-year? And if that's the case, what's the kind of exit strategy you're looking for? And then w
componenttext: Can you provide a bit more color on the composition of the inventory by product category? Should we see watches are up high single to low double digits year-over-year? And if that's the case, what's the kind of exit strategy you're looking for? And then where do you think inventories will stack up for next quarter?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the inventory -- our inventory was up 7%, which is obviously outpacing the sales growth in the business, higher than we planned. The growth is primarily in our strongest selling brands. But as you have falling demand just given lead times, it takes a
componenttext: Yes, the inventory -- our inventory was up 7%, which is obviously outpacing the sales growth in the business, higher than we planned. The growth is primarily in our strongest selling brands. But as you have falling demand just given lead times, it takes a while to turn through it. So we see most of that as a timing issue that we ultimately can work through. I did mention earlier that we are a bit heavier given the performance in markets like Asia on our Swiss inventories, and we're working through those as well.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And can you talk about the intellectual property you acquired with Misfit? And also what's your current R&D rate as a percent of sales and how should we think about the step-up function for that for next year?
componenttext: And can you talk about the intellectual property you acquired with Misfit? And also what's your current R&D rate as a percent of sales and how should we think about the step-up function for that for next year?

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: In regards to Misfit and the IP, as we talked about earlier, this is a unique platform in both cloud and app and then the ability to have an engineering team that really is driving our product platform. So it's multi-brand. It connects to the Internet of
componenttext: In regards to Misfit and the IP, as we talked about earlier, this is a unique platform in both cloud and app and then the ability to have an engineering team that really is driving our product platform. So it's multi-brand. It connects to the Internet of Things and communities that our customers care about. And basically, their low-power management platform that's built on watch technology or watch rechargeable -- nonrechargeable batteries, coin cell, fits very well with our roadmap and the technology we're trying to bring into our watches.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just on the earlier question. Our comp was driven more by the outlets, which were slightly up. The full-price store is slightly down.
componenttext: Just on the earlier question. Our comp was driven more by the outlets, which were slightly up. The full-price store is slightly down.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that does conclude our question-and-answer session. I'll turn the call back to the speakers for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: And that does conclude our question-and-answer session. I'll turn the call back to the speakers for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much for participating in the call today and we look forward to talking to you after our fourth quarter call in February. Thank you very much.
componenttext: Thank you very much for participating in the call today and we look forward to talking to you after our fourth quarter call in February. Thank you very much.

headline: Fossil Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
